channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Libya: Political Transition Extended
item.description: Libya’s interim Parliament voted to extend the country’s postrevolutionary transition, giving itself an extra year to oversee the writing of a constitution and the holding of elections, members said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Palestinian Hunger Striker Freed
item.description: The Palestinian, Samer Issawi, had taken only water and infusions from Aug. 1, 2012, until April 23 of this year, becoming a symbol of the Palestinian struggle against Israel
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Are You Qualified to Be a Journalist in China? Take the Test
item.description: Chinese reporters are studying hundreds of pages of materials on Chinese-style journalism in order to pass a test early next year to renew their official press cards.
item.dc:creator: By MIA LI and BREE FENG
item.media:description: A policeman stands guard outside the Southern Weekly newspaper in Guangzhou last January after reporters went on strike over a scrapped New Year's editorial. Next year, reporters will have to pass a new exam to keep their press cards.

item.title: Archbishop and Imam Are United Across Battle Lines in Central African Republic
item.description: Archbishop Dieudonné Nzapalainga and Imam Oumar Kobine Layama have joined forces in Central African Republic, where a brutal conflict between Christians and Muslims has killed hundreds this month alone.
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL
item.media:description: A young man tried to help a friend who was badly injured by Chadian troops during a protest outside an airport in Bangui, Central African Republic.

item.title: British Premier Faces Growing Criticism Over a Push to Curb Immigration
item.description: Fractures within Britain’s governing coalition add to the pressure on Prime Minister David Cameron as debate over limits on European Union immigrants intensifies.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Happy Birthday, Chairman Mao
item.description: With Mao’s 120th birthday approaching, some preparations are heating up while others have been scaled down, reflecting a desire at the top of the party for a more modest affair for a leader both revered and hated.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: A girl poses next to a 3D painting of Mao Zedong at an exhibition in Binzhou, Shandong Province.

item.title: Korea Execution Is Tied to Clash Over Businesses
item.description: The execution of the uncle of North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, had its roots in a firefight along the country’s southwestern coast over who would profit from its most lucrative exports.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN and DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: Jang Song-thaek, the uncle of the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, was executed immediately after he was convicted of treason in a special military court on Dec. 12.

item.title: $40 Million in Aid Set for Bangladesh Garment Workers
item.description: The fund for the Rana Plaza factory building collapse is considered a landmark in compensating families of garment industry victims, in terms of both the amount to be paid and the sophistication of the arrangements.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE
item.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Rana Plaza ruins, where over 1,100 died.

item.title: U.N. Chief Urges Steps to Calm South Sudan’s Growing Conflict
item.description: Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon is seeking a near doubling of the peacekeeping force in South Sudan, where civil war has become a rising threat.
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS KULISH, MICHAEL R. GORDON and SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Memo From Istanbul: Growing Mistrust Between U.S. and Turkey Is Played Out in Public
item.description: After several years of close ties, the United States and Turkey find themselves at odds on a number of issues.
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO
item.media:description: At the United States Embassy in Ankara, Turkey, on Monday, protesters denounced Ambassador Francis J. Ricciardone Jr.

item.title: New York Immigrants Send Gifts Far Away, to Those Close at Heart
item.description: Roosevelt Avenue in Queens is crowded with shipping companies that serve the native countries of many immigrants in the city during the holidays.
item.dc:creator: By SARAH MASLIN NIR
item.media:description: Packages of necessities have been sent to the Philippines, where Typhoon Haiyan hit last month.

item.title: Russia Sends Vehicles to Syrian Port to Aid in Removal of Chemical Weapons Stockpile
item.description: The Russian Defense Ministry said 50 trucks and 25 armored vehicles were sent to Syria for the latest phase of the plan for destroying the stockpile.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN and ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Choir With Elite Pedigree Promotes Red Songs, and Red Values
item.description: If a choir committed both to socialism and a rule that limits membership to the children of Communist Party officials seems like a contradiction, perhaps it is because of the increasingly malleable notion of what it means to be “red” in China today.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM CENTURY
item.media:credit: Adam Century for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of the Founding Figures choir performing at an event in Beijing marking the upcoming 120th anniversary of Mao Zedong's birth.

item.title: Sweets Made Only for Christmas Are Spanish Town’s Gift to Itself
item.description: Factories in Estepa, Spain, produce traditional sugary confections for the holidays, giving the local economy a much-needed lift.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:credit: Laura Leon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Workers at the La Colchona factory last week in Estepa, Spain. The seasonal work provides the townspeople with scarce jobs.

item.title: Released Punk Rockers Keep Up Criticism of Putin
item.description: Critics said recent releases underscored the arbitrariness of the Russian justice system, as well as President Vladimir V. Putin’s singular authority.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: Maria Alyokhina spoke to reporters in Nizhny Novgorod on Monday.

item.title: The Lede: Defiant Remarks From Pussy Riot Activists as They Step From Prison
item.description: Two members of the feminist band Pussy Riot, Maria Alyokhina and Nadezhda Tolokonnikova, emerged from Russian prison colonies on Monday with defiant remarks.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: U.S. Softens Deadline for Deal to Keep Troops in Afghanistan
item.description: The Obama administration is backing away from its tough talk about a total withdrawal if the agreement is not finalized by Dec. 31.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG

item.title: Deep Russia-Germany Ties Behind a Prisoner’s Release
item.description: The issue of freedom for Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky has long been a topic of discussion and negotiation between leaders of the two countries.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE

item.title: Delhi Politician, in Post Known for Its Perks, Says No Thanks
item.description: Signaling a new attitude, Delhi’s new chief minister promised that neither he nor his ministers would take up residence in the beautiful homes left by the British.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS
item.media:description: Arvind Kejriwal, Delhi’s new chief minister, is greeted by supporters as he arrives for a public meeting in New Delhi on Sunday.

item.title: When Britons Drink Till They Drop
item.description: Police officers in Northampton, England, say binge drinking has become a serious public hazard.

item.title: As Violence Rises, Journalists in Iraq Face Renewed Risks
item.description: A suicide attack on a television station in Tikrit underscores a stepped-up campaign by Al Qaeda against journalists, who also face the wrath of officials.
item.dc:creator: By YASIR GHAZI

item.title: The Lede: American Gets One-Year Sentence for Spoof Video in United Arab Emirates
item.description: A state security court in the United Arab Emirates handed a one-year sentence to an American man and two Indians for making a satirical video deemed a threat to the nation.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTINE HAUSER

item.title: The Lede: A Twitter Message About AIDS, Followed by a Firing and an Apology
item.description: A Manhattan public relations executive loses her job after a post on Twitter about AIDS, race and Africa created an online furor.
item.dc:creator: By ASHLEY SOUTHALL

item.title: Mikhail Kalashnikov, Creator of AK-47, Dies at 94
item.description: General Kalashnikov sometimes lamented the weapon’s unchecked distribution but took pride in having invented the rifle, the most abundant firearm ever made.
item.dc:creator: By C. J. CHIVERS
item.media:description: Lt. Gen. Mikhail T. Kalashnikov, the inventor of the AK-47, holding a prototype of his famous assault rifle in 2007.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: December 23
item.description: A rescue operation drill in Agartala, Tripura.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: A man, lying on a stretcher, being rescued by fire service personnel during a rescue operation drill in Agartala, Tripura.
